bibl.title: Letter from Florence M. Read to Henry Rose Carter, September 15, 1921

div1.p: Read describes details of a field trip. She mentions the attitude of the laborers, noting that the military is needed to get work done. She discusses the prophylactic campaign initiative.

September 15, 1921
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
You will be both interested and amused in the
following quotation from a recent letter from Doctor Hanson:

"The condition in each of those places (Chicama,
Chocope) however is such that there can be no propagation in
either place. To illustrate I will illustrate by telling you
of the incident which occured on our Inspection of Paijan,
Chocope and Ascope on Sunday July 12th. In accordance with the
custom which we have employed in Libertad during my visits there,
we have taken a R.R. motor car for the purpose of making a rapid
survey on Sundays when the Inspectors are not occupied with the
daily routine, and take all of the supervising inspectors to
different places, to make the inspections. The inspectors are
each assigned a section of the town visited, I and the other
Medicos also each taking a section, in order to cover the entire
place in a very short time. On the occasion referred to in
Paijan the same distribution was made, but before setting out on
this work Mr Corrigan and Sr. Ramirez were so certain that we
would not find any breeding that they bet us a bottle of wine that
we would find no larvae in either, Paijan, Chocope or Chicama.
After an inspection of about 200 houses we found one larva in a
flour vase and one dead pupa in a chamber under a bed, the only
evidence of stegomya found in Paijan that day. With conditions
of the kind I believe it safe to say that the epidemic will not
continue, however, Corrigan and Ramirez lost their bottle of wine.

"The entire Department of Libertad is in very satis-
factory condition with the exception of Casa Grande, where the
bolsheviki attitude of the laborers has been such that we have

not been able to complete the job. This, however, is
receiving attention, and the Prefecto has given us sufficient
troops to carry out the necessary measures there. In addition
to this place a little more work will be needed at Laredo,
Cartavia and Santi Ago de Cao before we are completely certain
of everything. Nevertheless I believe that have had our last
case.

“In order not to leave anything undone which might
result in a repetition of this years experience, I have with
the approval of Dr. White started a prophylactic campaign in the
Department of Ancash and expect to carry it all the way to Lima
and Callao.”
